text: A Psalm of David. The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool .
text_kjv: A Psalm of David. The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool .
text_niv: Psalm 110Of David. A psalm.The Lord says to my Lord:“Sit at my right handuntil I make your enemiesa footstool for your feet.”
text_esv: The LORD says to my Lord: “Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies your footstool.”
text_nlt: The LORD said to my Lord,“Sit in the place of honor at my right handuntil I humble your enemies,making them a footstool under your feet.”

text_nasb: A Psalm of David. The LORD says to my Lord: 'Sit at My right hand Until I make Your enemies a footstool for Your feet.'
context: Psalm 110 stands out as one of the most frequently quoted Old Testament passages in the New Testament, often cited in reference to Jesus. To understand its significance, we must consider its historical and cultural milieu. David, the traditionally ascribed author, reigned as king of Israel around 1000 BC. Kings in the ancient Near East held absolute power, acting as both political and military leaders. The phrase 'right hand' signified a place of honor and authority; to sit at someone's right hand meant sharing in their power and dominion. The 'footstool' imagery symbolizes complete subjugation and victory over enemies, a common motif in ancient royal ideology. The concept of a king also being a priest was unusual in Israel, where the priestly lineage stemmed from Levi. However, figures like Melchizedek, king of Salem and priest of God Most High, presented a precedent. His priesthood was considered superior and predated the Levitical priesthood. Understanding the Davidic covenant, where God promised David an eternal dynasty, is also crucial. While the immediate descendants of David sat on the throne, the psalm hints at a future, greater king who would not only reign but also possess a unique priestly authority. The psalm's brevity and profound implications made it a subject of intense theological debate and interpretation throughout Jewish and Christian history. Its regal language and declaration of divine authority resonate with the expectations surrounding the Messiah, who was anticipated to be both a king and a deliverer.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 110:1 presents a powerful statement about the relationship between God the Father and the Messiah, who Christians believe to be Jesus Christ. 'The LORD said unto my Lord' establishes a distinction between two distinct yet interconnected figures. The first 'LORD' (YHWH) refers to God the Father, while the second 'Lord' (Adonai) is understood by Christians as referring to the Messiah. The invitation to 'Sit thou at my right hand' signifies the bestowing of supreme authority and honor upon the Messiah by God the Father. This isn't merely a symbolic gesture; it indicates a shared dominion and participation in God's power and glory. 'Until I make thine enemies thy footstool' speaks to the ultimate victory that the Messiah will achieve over all opposition to God's kingdom. This imagery is often interpreted as encompassing not only earthly enemies but also spiritual forces of evil. The 'footstool' symbolizes absolute and complete subjugation, indicating that no power can ultimately withstand the Messiah's reign. This verse, when viewed through a Christian lens, is a profound affirmation of Jesus' divine status and authority. It suggests that Jesus, as the Messiah, shares in God's eternal power and will ultimately triumph over all evil. The verse also lays the foundation for understanding the Trinity, as it distinguishes between the Father and the Son while simultaneously highlighting their unified purpose and shared dominion. The future tense 'until I make' indicates a process, suggesting that the Messiah's victory is being progressively realized throughout history.
application: Psalm 110:1, though written millennia ago, offers profound practical applications for modern believers. First, it reminds us of Jesus' ultimate authority. In a world filled with uncertainty and chaos, knowing that Jesus is seated at the right hand of God, reigning supreme, provides immense comfort and security. We can trust in His leadership and guidance, even when circumstances seem overwhelming. Second, the verse challenges us to align our lives with God's will. If Jesus is indeed Lord, then our actions, thoughts, and attitudes should reflect that reality. This means submitting to His teachings, seeking His guidance through prayer and Scripture, and striving to live a life that is pleasing to Him. Third, the promise of ultimate victory over enemies offers hope in the face of adversity. We all face challenges and struggles, whether they be personal battles with sin, relational conflicts, or societal injustices. Knowing that God will ultimately make our enemies His footstool empowers us to persevere through difficult times, trusting that He will bring justice and redemption. Fourth, the verse calls us to active participation in God's kingdom. While the ultimate victory belongs to Jesus, we are called to be His ambassadors, spreading the Gospel and working towards the establishment of His kingdom on earth. This involves acts of service, compassion, and advocacy for the marginalized. Fifth, the verse emphasizes the importance of worship and adoration. Recognizing Jesus' divine authority and kingship should inspire us to worship Him with reverence and gratitude. This can manifest in various ways, including prayer, singing, reading Scripture, and acts of service. Ultimately, Psalm 110:1 calls us to a life of faith, obedience, and active participation in God's kingdom, grounded in the assurance of Jesus' ultimate victory.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you acknowledging your sovereignty and power. I thank you for the gift of your Son, Jesus Christ, who sits at your right hand, reigning in glory. Lord, help me to truly grasp the magnitude of His authority and to submit my life fully to His Lordship. Strengthen my faith, so that I may trust in His promises and persevere through trials, knowing that He will ultimately triumph over all evil. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may be a faithful ambassador for your kingdom, spreading the Gospel and serving others in love. Help me to worship you with reverence and gratitude, recognizing the immeasurable gift of salvation you have freely given. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Psalm 110 is heavily quoted because it provides crucial Messianic prophecies about Jesus' kingship and priesthood. Its imagery of a divine figure seated at God's right hand aligns perfectly with the New Testament's portrayal of Jesus' ascension and authority.
faqs.question: Q1: Why is Psalm 110 so often quoted in the New Testament?

faqs.answer: The 'enemies' encompass both earthly adversaries and spiritual forces opposing God's kingdom. This includes personal struggles with sin, systemic injustice, and the influence of evil in the world, all ultimately overcome by Christ.
faqs.question: Q2: Who are the 'enemies' mentioned in Psalm 110:1?

faqs.answer: Psalm 110:1 provides a basis for understanding the Trinity by distinguishing between God the Father ('The LORD') and God the Son ('my Lord') while highlighting their shared dominion and cooperative effort in salvation.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the concept of the Trinity?

faqs.answer: Being seated at God's right hand signifies sharing in God's authority, power, and glory. It indicates a position of honor and dominion, suggesting that Jesus is actively involved in governing the universe.
faqs.question: Q4: What does it mean to say Jesus is 'seated' at God's right hand?

faqs.answer: By remembering Jesus' ultimate authority and victory, we can find hope and strength in facing daily struggles. Trusting in His power allows us to persevere, knowing He is working towards our good and His glory, even amid difficulty.
